bodyText:
The neural basis of neuroprosthetic skill learning 
 
 
 
   
   
 Jose Carmena , University of California, Berkeley
   
   
   
 Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) is a novel technology that holds great potential to aid large numbers of people with sensory, motor and cognitive disabilities.
 BMIs provide also a framework for examining basic neuroscience questions, especially those related to the understanding of how neural plasticity relates to the acquisition and consolidation of neuroprosthetic skills, i.e. accurate, readily-recalled control
 of disembodied actuators irrespective of natural physical movement. In this talk I will postulate that achieving skillful, natural control of a multi-degree-of-freedom prosthetic device will entail synergizing two different types of adaptation processes: natural
 (brain plasticity) and artificial (decoder adaptation), as well as providing realistic sensory feedback from the prosthetic device. I will present recent work from our laboratory showing that 1) neuroplasticity facilitates consolidation of neuroprosthetic
 motor skill in a way that resembles that of natural motor learning; 2) corticostriatal plasticity is necessary for neuroprosthetic skill learning, and 3) closed-loop decoder adaptation (CLDA) techniques can expedite the learning process by adapting the decoder
 parameters during closed-loop BMI operation (i.e., while the subject is using the BMI).  We believe that BMI systems capable of exploiting both neuroplasticity and CLDA will be able to boost learning, generalize well to novel movements and environments, and
 ultimately achieve a level of control and dexterity comparable to that of natural arm movements. 
   
   
 CELEST Science of Learning Seminar Series 
   
 Friday, May 9, 2014 at 2:00pm 
   
 Boston University 
 677 Beacon Street 
 Auditorium, Room B02 
 Refreshments will be served after the talk in Room B03
 
   
 For more information on upcoming events, visit
 http://celest.bu.edu

 Center for Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology
 
 Senior Program Coordinator
 
 677 Beacon Street 
 Boston, MA 02215

bodyText:
Hey Misha -  Could be of interest to you.  Caroline ---------- Forwarded message ---------- 
From: Pattie Maes < pattie@media.mit.edu > 

Date: Sat, Feb 15, 2014 at 3:03 PM Subject: Talk on "Mindfulness and Neurofeedback" - Fri 2/21 3pm - E14-633 - Prof Judson Brewer To: msgs@media.mit.edu , ml-all@media.mit.edu 


 
 

 
 
 
 
  



  



   



    Mindfulness and
    Neurofeedback, Friday 2/21 Professor Judson Brewer,
    University of Massachusetts Medical School 
   
   
  
   
    Abstract 



   Over the past decade, there has been an explosion of
   interest in how contemplative practices such as meditation
   can inform science and how science can inform these
   practices. Recent advances have begun to unravel the
   mysteries of how mindfulness practice can affect learning
   processes leading to positive habit change. Using evidence
   from clinical trials of smoking cessation, this presentation
   will first map out how mindfulness targets key components of
   operant conditioning pathways. It will then detail
   neuroscientific findings from novice and expert meditators
   using traditional and real-time fMRI to link the subjective
   experience of effortless awareness that may be a key aspect
   of mindfulness, to regional brain activity in the default
   mode network. It will conclude with a discussion of how
   targeted neurofeedback may provide a “mental mirror” for
   augmenting mindfulness training. 
    
    Bio 



   Judson Brewer MD PhD is the Director of Research at the
   Center for Mindfulness and associate professor in medicine
   and psychiatry at UMass Medical School. He also is adjunct
   faculty at Yale University, and a research affiliate at MIT.
   A psychiatrist and internationally known expert in
   mindfulness training for addictions, Brewer has developed
   and tested novel mindfulness programs for addictions,
   including both in-person and app-based treatments. He has
   also studied the underlying neural mechanisms of mindfulness
   using standard and real-time fMRI, and is currently
   translating these findings into clinical use. He has
   published numerous peer-reviewed articles and book chapters,
   spoken at international conferences, presented to the US
   President’s Office of National Drug Control Policy, been
   featured at TEDx, Time magazine (top 100 new health
   discoveries of 2013), Forbes, Businessweek, NPR and the BBC
   among others. He writes an addiction blog for The Huffington
   Post.
subject: Talk on "Mindfulness and Neurofeedback" - Fri 2/21 3pm - E14-633 - Prof Judson Brewer

bodyText:
Hi, I thought you might interest this talk. I will go,might see you there.  Best, -- Andrés  ---------- Forwarded message ---------- 
From: Kathleen Sullivan < kdsulliv@csail.mit.edu > Date: Tue, Apr 29, 2014 at 3:50 PM Subject: [Talk] Mon. May 5, 4pm, 32-D463 - Emanuel Parzen "LP Statistical Science (Nonparametric Modeling, Exploratory Big Data Analysis)" 
To: 
 
 
 
 
  LP Statistical Science (Nonparametric Modeling, Exploratory Big
  Data Analysis) 
 Speaker: Emanuel
  Parzen , Department of Statistics, Texas A&M University 
 Date: Monday, May 5 
 Time: 4:00pm – 5:00pm 
 Location: Star Conference Room, 32-D463 
 Host: Tomaso Poggio, CBMM, BCS, MIBR, CSAIL, LCSL 
  
  Abstract :  Statisticians in the 21st century can look forward
 to very bright futures for the discipline and profession of
 statistics by solving the important problem of teaching thousands
 statistical data scientist aspirants, what are the fundamental
 methods of statistical learning. We are developing a framework that
 unifies parametric and nonparametric models, frequentist and
 Bayesian inference, small data and big data, beginning courses that
 differ from traditional courses by teaching methods for simple data
 in ways that extend to complex high dimensional data (similar to the
 goal of teaching finite dimensional math in the notation that extend
 to Hilbert space). To accomplish the above, a theory, called LP
 STATISTICAL SCIENCE, is being developed by myself and Subhadeep
 (Deep) Mukhopadhyay (Temple University Fox School of Business). The
 theory is unifying because it applies to mixed data (variables which
 are discrete or continuous) and to population and sample
 distributions. It practices "plug-in estimation" computed for sample
 distributions by the same definitions used for population
 distributions. 
  
  Short Bio :  Emanuel Parzen is a Distinguished Professor
 Emeritus, Dept. of Statistics, Texas A&M University. He has
 served as an Assistant Professor of Mathematical Statistics at
 Columbia, Professor of Statistics at Stanford, a Leading
 Professor-Chairman of the Dept. of Statistics and a Director of
 Statistical Science at the State University of New York at Buffalo,
 and a Distinguished Professor at Texas A&M University. He has
 been a Fellow at Imperial College London, IBM Systems Research
 Institute, the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences
 at Stanford, and a Visiting Professor at the Sloan School of MIT,
 the Dept. of Statistics at Harvard and the Dept. of Biostatistics at
 Harvard. Professor Parzen has authored or coauthored over 120 papers
 and 6 books, on signal detection theory, time series analysis and
 non-parametric statistics. He pioneered the use of kernel density
 estimation (also known as the Parzen window in his honor) and
 Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces (RKHS) in statistics and
 engineering. He has served on innumerable editorial boards and
 national committees, and has organized several influential
 conferences and workshops. He has been elected Fellow of the
 American Statistical Association, the Institute of Mathematical
 Statistics and the American Association for the Advancement of
 Science. In 1994, he was awarded the prestigious Samuel S. Wilks
 Memorial Medal by the American Statistical Association. 
  
 Relevant URL: http://lcsl.mit.edu/#/events/ seminars 
  
 Open to: the general public 
  
 This talk is part of the LCSL "Machine Learning Seminar Series"
 organized by the Laboratory for Computational and Statistical
 Learning (LCSL) (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute
 of Technology), and coordinated with the Center for Brains, Minds
 and Machines (CBMM). 
  
  -- 
Kathleen D. Sullivan
Center Manager
Center for Brains, Minds and Machines (CBMM)
McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences

(617) 253-0551

bodyText:
UPCOMING EVENT: CompNet Seminar   
    
 A sensorimotor role for oscillations in visual cortex  
    
 Christopher Pack, McGill University
    
 Oscillations are frequently observed in recordings of neural activity, including in local field potential (LFP) signals, where they
 probably represent network activity on a scale of a few hundred microns. At certain frequencies, LFP oscillations appear to modulate single-neuron excitability, suggesting that they provide a means of organizing perception through time. In this talk I will
 suggest that oscillations provide an interface between the oculomotor and visual systems. Recordings from multi-electrode arrays in V4 of macaque monkeys show that saccades shape the pattern of oscillatory activity across retinotopic space in such a way as
 to prioritize the processing of behaviorally relevant information. 
 
    
 Friday, May 2, 2014 at 2:00pm 
    
    
 Boston University

 Refreshments to follow.

---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: Joseph S Perkell < jperkell@mit.edu > 
Date: Wed, Apr 23, 2014 at 5:02 PM Subject: FW: SPECIAL SEMINAR: NLM Lecture | Michael Long | How does the brain	generate sequences for behavior? | Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM To: "Guenther, Frank H" < guenther@bu.edu > 
 





 
 
 Hi Frank,  
 There might be some interest in this among your group members.  
 Cheers,  
 Joe  
 
 
 
 From:  bcs-talks-bounces@MIT.EDU [mailto: bcs-talks-bounces@MIT. EDU ]
 On Behalf Of Dept of Brain and Cognitive Sciences 
 Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2014 3:58 PM 
 To: bcs-all@MIT.EDU ; bcs-talks@MIT.EDU 
 Subject: SPECIAL SEMINAR: NLM Lecture | Michael Long | How does the brain generate sequences for behavior? | Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM
  
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
     
 
 
 Neurobiology of Learning and Memory Lecture (NLM)   

 
    
 
 How does the brain generate sequences for behavior?  
 
Dr. Michael Long  
 
Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM 
Singleton Auditorium, 46-3002  
 
 Host : Edward Nieh  
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
Complex motor sequences such as speaking are central to our everyday lives, but little is known about the relevant microcircuitry enabling these behaviors.  In the zebra finch, a dedicated cortical sequence-generating nucleus known as HVC controls song production. 
 Using a range of experimental techniques to manipulate and monitor circuit activity, we have begun to establish a mechanistic understanding of the cellular and circuit activity underlying premotor sequence generation in the zebra finch.  Specifically, we have
 uncovered the mechanisms by which network sparsity is achieved and the role of recurrent sensory feedback in the maintenance of premotor patterns.  Through initial investigations into mammalian vocal production circuitry, we are attempting to generalize our
 findings across systems.  
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 Michael Long’s research focuses on understanding the mechanisms by which neurons work together to enable skilled movements. Towards that end, he has developed innovative approaches to monitor and manipulate motor-related neural circuits underlying complex
 behavioral sequences.  His work extends to a variety of model systems, including humans, songbirds, and a wild-caught Costa Rican rodent species. 
  
 
In his young career, Michael has received a number of awards and fellowships including the Esther A. & Joseph Klingenstein Fellowship Award in the Neurosciences, the Rita Allen Foundation Scholars Award, and the Robertson Investigator Award from the New York
 Stem Cell Foundation. Dr. Long received his PhD from Brown University, and he completed his postdoctoral training in the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT.

bodyText:
From Mark Kramer:  
 FYI:  Dr. Nathan Killian from MGH will speak at our data analysis lab meeting  on Friday .  He recently found grid cells in primate cortex - see the Nature article here: 
 http://www.nature.com/nature/ journal/v491/n7426/full/ nature11587.html 
 Time/Date:   3 PM, April 25 
 Location:  111 Cummington Mall, Boston, MA.  Room 241 
 Title:  Visual Memory in the Primate Entorhinal Cortex 
 Abstract: 
 The entorhinal cortex (EC) in the medial temporal lobe plays a critical role in memory formation and is implicated in several neurological diseases including temporal lobe epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease. Despite the known importance of this brain region, deeper investigation of the normal bioelectrical activity patterns of the EC in awake, behaving primates is necessary. I recorded the activity of individual neurons and populations of neurons in the EC of rhesus macaque monkeys during free-viewing of photographs. The results of these experiments help to explain how primates form memories of, and navigate through, the visual world. Neurons were discovered in the EC that represent visual space with triangular grid receptive fields. This property is similar to grid cells previously described in the rodent EC, but here the neuronal responses relate to viewing of remote space as opposed to representing the physical location of the animal. Intermixed with spatial neurons were neurons that encoded aspects of recognition memory. Interesting activity patterns related to recognition memory were further present at the population level. Synchronization within the gamma-band (30-140 Hz) in superficial layers of the EC was modulated by stimulus novelty, while the strength of memory formation modulated gamma-band synchronization in the deep layers and in layer III. Furthermore, the strength of connectivity in the gamma-band between different layers was correlated with the strength of memory formation: deep to superficial power transfer was correlated with stronger memory formation and superficial to deep transfer was correlated with weaker memory formation. These findings support previous investigations of hippocampal-entorhinal connectivity in the rodent and advance our understanding of the functional circuitry of the medial temporal lobe memory system. 
 

 


 

--

bodyText:
Dear all, 
 
  This Friday, Sam Ling, from the Department of Psychological & Brain Sciences at Boston University will present in our Friday journal club. 
 
  Given the classical thought that LGN does not process orientation information, it should be a very stimulating talk. Below, please find the abstract that Sam provided for us: 
 
Title: Does the LGN process orientation information? 
 
Abstract: Ever since Hubel & Wiesel, the standard models for early vision have typically assumed that orientation selectivity first emerges in visual cortex, with little contribution from the retina and the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN). This assumption was largely based on the idea that receptive fields the LGN and retina are concentric, and thus are incapable of coding orientation information. A growing body of empirical results, however, indicates that the notion of circular ON-OFF receptive fields may be oversimplified: receptive fields within both the LGN and the retina have been shown to have a tendency to be elongated, in a manner that would support orientation-selective processing prior to cortex. I will provide a survey of the empirical literature examining this possibility, with the hope that this will spur discussion as to whether this has any ramifications for current models of visual processing. 
 
 
  Hope to see you all. 

  Arash

bodyText:
Wednesday, 4/2, 4pm, MCS241 Talker: Michelle M. McCarthy  Talk:  Multiple time scale dynamics of excitation-induced pauses in globus pallidus neurons 
 Abstract: 
The basal ganglia consist of a set of subcortical nuclei that function in coordination of movement, habit formation, and reward-based learning. Dysfunction of the basal ganglia is associated with a host of neurologic and psychiatric diseases including Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, addiction and depression. The central nucleus of the BG is the globus pallidus externus (GPe). Approximately half of GPe neurons regularly display pauses in their spiking activity. Both the function and the mechanism of these pauses are currently undetermined. Computational modeling has identified a possible mechanism for these pauses. The mechanism is excitation-induced and depends on two slow membrane currents with widely different time scales. The proposed mechanism has readily apparent functional implications for the larger basal ganglia network. We discuss approaches to characterizing the key dynamical interactions that promote pauses in order to identify specific physiological conditions mediating both function and dysfunction in these networks.  


 


 

--

bodyText:
Dear all, 
 
  This Friday, at 1 pm, 3rd floor, Eric will host our Friday-JC. 
  I strongly encourage the current and past students of CN530 to join us; as well, highly recommended to all. 
 
  The abstract of Eric’s talk follows: 
 
 
During the past 15 years, the von der Heyt lab has generated a series of extremely interesting papers suggesting that 
many neurons in primate V2 respond to not only to contrast derivatives (as in V1, LGN, and retina) but also to 
"boundary ownership". This amounts to a form of structured "edge" in which "ownership" of a nearby "shape" 
is explicitly encoded in the neuronal response. In this meeting, this finding will be discussed in the larger context of 
the problem of “Neuronal Representation". The various theories of representation that have been considered range over 
the single cell feature extraction (grandmother cell), Gestalt ideas of "one-to-one" representation, Gibsonian ideas 
of "perception-action", topographic representation (via maps/columns), and von der Heydt's "boundary ownership". 
The discussion will focus on these various conceptual frameworks, and, in particular, von der Heydt's apparent rejection of 
the notion of a surface based representation (neo-Gestalt?) in favor of a pure, but structured, "edge" representation. 
 
An example of a recent "retinex" solution will be shown, in order to illustrate the difficulty with this idea, and to make explicit what an 
"edge" versus "surface" representation actually "looks" like, and the problematic, though intriguing nature of some of von der Heydt's 
thinking in this area. 
 
  Hope to see you all, 
  Arash 
p.s. check out a few attached PDFs 
 
============================ 
Arash Yazdanbakhsh, MD, PhD, 
Research Assistant Professor, 
Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology (CompNet) 
Program in Cognitive and Neural Systems, Boston University 
Center of Excellence for Learning in Education, Science and Technology 
http://cns.bu.edu/~yazdan/

bodyText:
3:30pm (30 min early!), Wednesday (today), 2/26, MCS241 
 (Head to the CRC dinner afterwards!)  Ben Polletta presents:  
Ketamine-Induced ~140 Hz Oscillations in Nucleus Accumbens  I'll present a literature review on the so-called high frequency oscillations (HFOs) observed in the nucleus accumbens (NAC) with NMDAR blockade. After a brief review of the structure and hypothesized functions of the NAC, I'll talk about the phenomenology and pharmacology of ketamine-induced NAC HFOs. Then I'll review some modeling results with relevance to striatal circuits, and we'll do our best to work our way around to mechanistic hypotheses regarding the generation of HFOs in the presence of NMDAR antagonists. 



 


 
 
 


 

--

bodyText:
Network Neuroscience: From the Connectome to Brain Dynamics and Function  
   
 Olaf Sporns , Indiana University 
  
   
   
 Recent advances in network science have greatly increased our understanding of the structure and function of many networked systems, ranging from transportation networks, to social
 networks, the internet, ecosystems, and biochemical and gene transcription pathways.  Network approaches are also increasingly applied to the brain, at several levels of scale from cells to entire nervous systems. Early studies in this emerging field of brain
 connectomics have focused on mapping brain network topology and identifying some of its characteristic features, including small world attributes, modularity and hubs. More recently, the emphasis has shifted towards linking brain network topology to brain
 dynamics, the patterns of functional interactions that emerge from spontaneous and evoked neuronal activity.  I will give an overview of recent work characterizing the structure of complex brain networks, with particular emphasis on studies demonstrating how
 the network topology of the connectome constrains and shapes its capacity to process and integrate information.  
   
   
 CELEST Science of Learning Seminar Series  
   
 Friday, February 21, 2014 at 2:00pm

        We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University: 
 
 Learning When to See What: Spatiotemporal Sequence Recognition and Prediction in Primary Visual Cortex  
 Department of Biology 
Neurobiology Search Seminar 
 Dr. Jeffrey Gavornik, PhD 
MIT, The Picower Institute for Learning and Memory 
       
      
     

    
   
  
 
  
   
    

     
      

       

        Abstract: Sensory stimuli reach the brain as temporal sequences of spatial activation patterns driven by external events. Through experience, the brain learns to use this noisy and incomplete data to infer and predict the current and future states of its surroundings and to generate appropriate behaviors. Despite the fundamental importance of this ability as it relates to executive behavior and cognition, little is known about its neural basis. This talk will present evidence that visual experience can encode specific predictive spatiotemporal sequence representations in primary visual cortex (V1). These findings support the hypothesis that temporal sequence coding is a fundamental ability of neocortical circuits, not a specialization of higher cortical association areas, and suggest that V1 can be used to mechanistically study how the brain uses past experience to make "intelligent guesses" based on limited information.

        We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University: 
 
 From Circuits to Behavior: New Concepts in Olfactory Processing  
 Department of Biology 
Neurobiology Search Seminar 
 Dr. David Gire 
Harvard Univeristy 
       
      
     

    
   
  
 
  
   
    

     
      

       

        Abstract: The complex patterns of neural activity in our brains do not recreate every detail of the external world, but rather efficiently and adaptively represent behaviorally relevant information derived from a constant stream of sensory input. This is particularly noticeable in the case of olfaction, since a smell is seldom experienced without a rich collection of learned associations. In this talk, I will present studies in the olfactory system that demonstrate both the neural codes used to efficiently represent behaviorally important information as well as the neural circuit mechanisms that support these codes. These studies provide new insights into the neural mechanisms through which sensory stimuli are combined with behavioral associations to generate efficient sensory codes in behaving animals.
       
      
     

    
   
  
 
  
   
    


 
  
   
    
     
      


       


      
     
    
    
     
      
        Seminar Details

	 We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University: 
 
	 The Cognitive Neuroscience of Remembering 
 
	 Anthony Wagner , Stanford University 
 
 Declarative memory permits an organism to bridge past and present, providing experience-dependent predictive information that informs current decisions and actions. Declarative memory critically depends on the medial temporal lobe (MTL) -- the hippocampal formation and surrounding parahippocampal gyrus -- as well as on interactions between the MTL and other cortical and subcortical structures. Recent progress in understanding human MTL function has come from the application of distributed pattern analyses of functional MRI data. In this talk, I will discuss how such analyses can be leveraged to delineate (a) the distinct computations subserved by MTL cortex and hippocampus in recognition memory, (b) the relationship between hippocampal and cortical processes at encoding and retrieval, and (c) the role of hippocampal-dependent pattern completion in across-event integration.

	 Friday, September 20, 2013 at 2:00pm

Oct. 15 Deadline for Proposal Request This message is from:  Office of Communications     The BU Center for Finance, Law & Policy is Issuing a Request for Proposals (RFP) that answers the following question: in the aftermath of the financial crisis, where do we go from here? Do you have a novel idea for how to better address financial risk? Or do you have an idea for research, a conference, or other project that will contribute to the ongoing discussions about financial reform or related issues? The BU Center for Finance, Law and Policy invites you to submit a brief proposal (no more than 4 pages) for interdisciplinary and collaborative research, education or other initiatives. This opportunity is open to BU faculty, staff and graduate students. Possibilities include but are not limited to: - Seed projects to explore novel ideas - Unusual and creative collaborative projects - Special events, workshops or symposia exploring promising interdisciplinary approaches to finance, financial regulation or risk management - Hosting and supporting visitors collaborating with BU researchers - Financial literacy initiatives and approaches to reach “unbanked” communities - Housing finance alternatives - Methods for measuring, monitoring and controlling systemic risk - Regulatory reform The deadline for submissions is Oct 15. For submission guidelines visit http://www.bu.edu/bucflp/rfp/ .  Oct. 21 RAD Self-Defense Class at BUMC This message is from:  Office of Communications     Location:  Solomon Carter Fuller Building, 85 East Newton St. Begins Monday, Oct. 21 Five week course on Mondays 4:30-7:30 p.m. Solomon Carter Fuller Building, 85 East Newton St. Rape Aggression Defense (RAD), a self-defense program specifically for women desiring to physically protect themselves against rape and other forms of violence, is being offered on the Medical Campus. The fee is $10 per person. Sign up online or visit us for more information at http://www.bu.edu/police/ services/RAD/ The RAD system is a realistic self-defense program of defensive tactics, techniques and education. It is a comprehensive course for women that follows a progression from awareness, prevention, risk reduction and avoidance to basic self-defense participation. The course includes an easy to read and well-illustrated student manual. This manual outlines the entire physical self-defense program and can be a reference for continued personal growth. The course is taught by BU Police RAD-certified instructors over twenty hours. Staff and Students looking to obtain the new version are asked to visit http://www.bumc.bu.edu/it/ support/site-licensed/ statistical/sas/ to download and install this software. For Staff and Faculty the price has increased slightly to $50 due to cost increases from the vendor. As in previous years BU currently offers SAS at no charge to BU students who are currently enrolled in classes that require SAS. If you have any questions about SAS, feel free to call the BUMC IT Service Desk at 638-5914.  Pick up free safety decals at the Parking Office and TranSComm This message is from:  Maureen Lacey, Director  maureenl@bu.edu  638- 7473 Location:  710 Albany St. Drop by the Parking Office and TranSComm (located at 710 Albany St.) to pick up small, clear “LOOK” decals. These decals cling to both side mirrors to remind drivers of cyclists riding toward you from either side of your car. Place these clear “clings” on all of your vehicles as a reminder to keep cyclists and drivers safe.  Research Study: Yoga for Depression This message is from:  Chris Streeter, MD  yogast@.bu.edu  638-8046 Location:  Solomon Carter Fuller Building   915A BUSM is conducting a research study to evaluate the effect of yoga postures and breathing practices on mild to moderate depression. If you are depressed and want to participate in a study that does not include anti-depressant medications, you may be eligible to participate. Subjects are compensated for their time. Please contact us at 638-8046 or yogast@bu.edu for more information.

 James Bradley Aimone, Ph.D.  
 Sandia National Laboratories  
    
 Title:  
 Adult Hippocampal Neurogenesis: Memory Resolution, Pattern Separation, or Both?  
    
 Abstract:  
 Over the past decade, adult neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus has received considerable attention
 due to its possible role in memory formation.  A growing debate in the neurogenesis community is whether new neurons simply enable the DG’s pattern separation role or whether they contribute some other unique function that had not previously been considered
 by the hippocampal field.  My talk will describe a biologically realistic computational model that has been designed to test the potential role of new neurons in both pattern separation and “memory resolution” – an alternative framework for viewing the DG’s
 function.  Further, I will describe how scaling the model to biologically realistic sizes is informative about what the value of new neurons are in human cognition.  Finally, I will show some new work on the impact of local network oscillations on new neurons
 and describe the potential role of this interaction on neurogenesis function. 
 
 

    

 


 

 
 
 
 -- 
 Xue Han, Ph.D. 
 Assistant Professor, Biomedical Engineering Department 
 Joint Professor, Dept. of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics 
 Member, Photonics Center 
 Boston University

From: Cheryl White [mailto: cheryl@coolidge.org ]
 
 Sent: Friday, April 05, 2013 5:58 PM 
 To: Swenson, Sarah Mae 
 Subject: CompNet's Frank Guenther at Coolidge Corner Theatre  
 
 
   
 Dear Sarah,  
   
 I wanted to touch base to let you know that Frank Guenther will be the guest speaker at the Coolidge Corner Theatre’s April 22 nd 
 Science on Screen program.  With Science on Screen , the Coolidge presents feature films and documentaries paired with science and technology experts.  This monthly series, now in its eighth season,
 is co-presented by The Museum of Science, Boston.  
   
 Professor Guenther will be speaking about brain-machine interfaces for locked-in patients before a screening of Julian Schnabel’s 2007 film
 The Diving Bell and the Butterfly .   A synopsis of the program appears below. I’m hoping you will spread the word to the CompNet community.  
   
 Please let me know if you have any questions.  I would be happy to email you a PDF of our program flyer for posting.  
   
 We’re looking forward to a compelling evening.  I hope you can join us.  
   
 Many thanks.  
   
 Best,  
   
 Cheryl White  
 Program Manager, Science on Screen  
 Coolidge Corner Theatre  
 cheryl@coolidge.org  
 617/699-7285  
   
 ______________________  
   
 Science on Screen Presents:  
 The Diving Bell and the Butterfly with 
cognitive and computational neuroscientist Frank Guenther  
 April 22 at 7:00 pm  
 Coolidge Corner Theatre, 290 Harvard Street, Brookline  
   
 In 1995, at age 43, Jean-Dominique Bauby, the successful and charismatic editor of
 Elle France magazine, suffered a massive stroke that left him with a rare condition called locked-in syndrome – mentally alert but unable to speak or move except for his left eye.   With the help of a speech therapist, he learned to communicate
 by blinking that eye to signify letters of the alphabet. Blink by blink, letter by letter, he dictated a memoir, which became an international bestseller and the basis for artist and director
 Julian Schnabel’s fiercely beautiful film. 
  Working with the brilliant cinematographer Janusz Kaminski ( Lincoln ,
 Saving Private Ryan ), Schnabel immerses us in Bauby's interior world — his memories, reveries, fantasies, loves and lusts — transforming a story of physical entrapment and spiritual renewal into exhilarating images.
  
   
 Join us before the film for a talk by Frank Guenther, a professor in the Departments of Speech, Language & Hearing Sciences and Biomedical Engineering at Boston University,
 where he also is Associate Director for the Graduate Program in Neuroscience.   Professor Guenther uses a combination of brain imaging and computational modeling to characterize the brain networks involved in speech, and develops brain-machine
 interfaces (BMIs) that can restore speech and other capabilities to patients with locked-in syndrome.  BMIs have produced astonishing laboratory demonstrations of locked-in patients controlling computers, speech synthesizers, and robotic arms using only their
 thoughts. Clinical trials are ongoing for several BMIs, promising a much more normal life for those with locked-in syndrome as these devices become widely available.  
   
 Part of the Coolidge Corner Theatre’s ongoing
 Science on Screen series. Tickets are $10 general admission or $8 students and Museum of Science members.  Coolidge Corner Theatre members get free admission.  For more information and to purchase tickets online, visit
 www.coolidge.org/content/ diving-bell-and-butterfly .  Tickets are also available at the Coolidge box office.
subject: FW: CompNet's Frank Guenther at Coolidge Corner Theatre

bodyText:
Hariri Institute announces Distinguished Lecture by Prof. Evimaria Terzi  
 
 
 Is this email not displaying correctly? 
 View it in your browser .
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
    
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Wednesdays @Hariri  
 3:00 PM   Wednesday, March 20, 2013 
 
   
 Distinguished Lecture  
 Jason Ritt 
Assistant Professor of Biomedical Engineering 
Hariri Institute Junior Faculty Fellow 
 
 Pinky and the Brain: Action and Actuation in the Sense of Touch   
 Abstract   
 
  
Stimulation neurotechnology encompasses an expanding range of applications, from deep brain stimulation to sensory prosthetics.  I will discuss our recent efforts in applying neurocontrol to understand and manipulate biological active touch.  By active, we
 mean that neural activity depends not only on feedforward stimuli, but also on rapid information-driven feedback to sensing behaviors.   The presence of this closed loop motivates sensory prosthetic designs as dynamical control devices, and not simple encoders
 of fixed neural activity patterns.  To investigate active sensing, we use real time neurofeedback to alter cortical activity in freely exploring mice, a key model system for the study of touch.   Mice explore objects of interest through rhythmic 5-20 Hz whisker
 motions, with rapidly changing whisking in response to object contacts.  We express the light sensitive ion channel Channelrhodopsin-2 (ChR2) in populations of neurons in primary somatosensory cortex (SI), allowing optogenetic stimulation.  Using custom chronic
 implants, we perform multi-electrode cortical recording and optogenetic stimulation in SI, with bilateral facial electromyograms (EMG) and high speed video to track volitional whisker movement.  Expanding on previous reports in head-fixed mice with randomly
 timed SI activation, we find that locking stimulation to volitional motions can strengthen and regularize whisking, loosely consistent with palpations of virtual objects.  I will discuss our ongoing efforts to embed the stimulation paradigm into psychophysical
 tasks and neurocontrol theory.  Of particular interest to computational scientists are theoretical challenges to finding neurocontrol strategies appropriate to the "underactuated" context of current stimulation technology.  These initial results are a step
 toward developing control systems for use in studies of neural coding during active sensing, and potential sensory prosthetic devices. 
   
 Professor Jason Ritt joined the Department of Biomedical Engineering in 2010. His current research concentrates on how organisms gather and use information from their environment,
 through active sensing and sensory decision-making. For example, Prof. Ritt and his students are studying the ways in which mice explore environments using their whiskers, employing a combination of computational analysis of high-speed video, electrophysiological
 recordings, and neurocontrol methods implemented by a real-time feedback system built on a digital signal processing architecture. He received his Ph.D. in neuroscience and a Masters in mathematics from Boston University.

bodyText:
Brains & Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 
 
Title: Slow Learning and Invariance 
Speaker: Andreas Maurer 
Date: 11-17-2011 
Time: 3:00 PM - 4:00 PM 
Location: Star Sem. Rm D463, Stata 
 
Abstract: The meaning of images observed in a natural sequence appears to 
evolve slowly, with comparatively few sudden changes. 
This principle of semantic continuity or slowness has been thought to play an 
important role in the formation of the mammalian visual cortex, and several 
machine learning algorithms have been proposed to exploit it for the learning 
of feature maps invariant under certain geometric transformations, such as 
translation, rotation or rescaling. 
The talk focuses on the relationship between the nature of the observed 
process and the class of semantic categories or invariances which can be 
learned from its observation using the slowness principle. Some simulations 
pertaining to the learning of scale invariance will also be presented. 
 
The Brains & Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 is being organized by the 
IIT@MIT lab (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology.) 
 
Relevant URL(S): http://cbcl.mit.edu

bodyText:
Reminder!  It's happening TOMORROW. ---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: Nan Jia < pacificmyth@gmail.com > 

Date: Fri, Nov 11, 2011 at 2:11 PM Subject: [CNSO] Seminar Nov. 17th: Florian Raudies - Fitting Psychometric Functions To: CNSO < cnso@cns.bu.edu >, celest-postdocs-all11@cns.bu. edu , celest-students-all11@cns.bu. edu 

 Hi All,  It is my pleasure to announce the next CNSO seminar, featuring our vision expert Florian Raudies.  The topic of this seminar will be Fitting Psychometric Functions with the abstract attached below. 



 Date: Thursday Nov. 17th Time: 11:30 - 12:30 Location: CompNet basement Lunch: pizza+soda will be served  Looking forward! 
 NaN  P.S:  The complete abstract file can be viewed here:   Florian's abstract 



 ============================== ============================== =================== Fitting psychometric functions contains several challenges. One challenge is the decision which parameters of the function should be optimized versus kept constant during optimization. Another is the sampling of the psychometric function that influences the optimization and the goodness of fit (Wichmann & Hill, Perception & Psychophysics 63(8), 2001). Thus, it is advised in the experiment design to account for proper sampling and make fewer assumptions by keeping parameters variable during the optimization. 



 I will present a maximum likelihood method (Treutwein & Strasburger, Perception & Psychophysics 61(1), 1999; Myung, Journal of Mathematical Psychology 47, 2003) estimating the parameters of psychometric functions given sampled data. Furthermore, I’ll elaborate on the topic of goodness of fit showing examples and giving interpretations.

bodyText:
FYI. 
 ---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: "Carolyn Suchy-Dicey" < organizers@neuphi.com > Date: Oct 18, 2011 6:15 PM Subject: Nancy Kanwisher, next Friday! 
To: Dear Neuphi-ites: Next Friday, October 28th , from 4 to 6 p.m. Nancy Kanwisher of MIT will be speaking about her work with fMRI, the title and abstract for which are below (the paper is attached): 

 Functional Specialization in the Human Brain: Evidence from fMRI 
  To
what extent is the human brain composed of functionally specialized
components, each optimized to solve a single mental task?  My lab has
used fMRI to identify three regions that are very specifically engaged
in the recognition of faces, places and bodies. The very existence of
these regions--in more or less the same place in every normal
subject--raises a host of new questions that I will address here. Are
specialized regions found only for evolutionarily old functions? Are
they found only for perceptual and motor systems, or also for abstract
higher-level thought? Can we develop new methods that can discover such
specializations even for functions that we do not hypothesize in
advance? How do specialized regions arise in development? Why do some
mental functions get their own private patch of real estate in the
brain and others (apparently) do not? In addition to highly specialized
regions, does the brain also have general-purpose regions that are
engaged across a wide range of tasks? We do not yet have answers to all
of these questions, but tantalizing clues are turning up all the time.  As with all Neuphi events, everyone is welcome to attend. The format normally involves a one hour talk followed by one hour of discussion. The website is http://www.neuphi.com for this and other events. As of now, the location is set for Room 525 of 745 Commonwealth Avenue (STH), but keep your eye(s) out for a room change in case I move it elsewhere. 

 I hope to see all of you soon! Best wishes, Carolyn Suchy-Dicey  -- Dr. Carolyn Suchy-Dicey Psychology Department 
Boston University 64 Cummington St. Boston, MA 02215 Philosophy Department Boston University 745 Commonwealth Ave. Boston, MA 02215 http://people.bu.edu/suchyd/

bodyText:
Come to Cog Lunch today for a stimulating talk and tasty food!  
 Title : Mechanisms of Peripheral Vision Explain Visual Search  Abstract :  Vision is an active process: we repeatedly move our eyes to seek out objects of interest and explore our environment.    Visual search experiments capture aspects of this process, by having subjects look for a target within a background of distractor objects. Search speed often correlates with target-distractor discriminability; search is faster when the target and distractors look quite different.    However, there are notable exceptions. A given discriminability can yield efficient searches (where the target seems to “pop-out”) as well as inefficient ones (where additional distractors make search significantly slower and more difficult).    Search is often more difficult when finding the target requires distinguishing a particular configuration or conjunction of features.    Search asymmetries abound.    These puzzling results have fueled three decades of theoretical and experimental studies.    We argue that the key issue in search is not the would-be appearance of items in the fovea, but rather the appearance of image patches in the periphery, where appearance is characterized by summary statistics computed over a sizable pooling region. By quantifying these statistics, we predict a set of classical search results, as well as peripheral discriminability of crowded patches such as those found in search displays.    Additional modeling allows us to quantitatively predict mean number of fixations to find the target. 
  Thanks, Sam
subject: Cog Lunch at Noon

bodyText:
The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT 
 
"Commonalities among programs that have shown great promise in working with ASD 
children" 
 
Adele Diamond, Ph.D., FRSC 
Canada Research Chair Tier 1 Professor of Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience, 
University of British Columbia (UBC), Vancouver 
 
6:00 p.m., Wednesday, October 19, 2011 
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception 
Building Address: 43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA 02139 
 
Hosted by John Gabrieli, Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Harvard-MIT 
Division of Health Sciences and Technology 
 
Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu 
 
Certain theater, juggling, and school curricular programs have achieved quite 
impressive success with children with ASD. They offer an alternative 
perspective to behavioral modification approaches on how to help children with 
ASD achieve their full potential and often find that that potential is far 
greater than people had previously imagined. That alternative perspective and 
the evidence for it will be elucidated. 
 
 
Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT 
(web.mit.edu/autism) 
________________________________________________________________________________ 
The Autism Consortium 2011 Symposium will take place on Tuesday, October 25, 
2011 at the Joseph B. Martin Conference Center at Harvard Medical School. 
 
Please register here: https://autismconsortium.eventbrite.com/ 
 
Registration opens at 8:30 AM. From 8:30 - 9:30 AM there will be a Family 
Resource and Research Fair with information booths featuring local autism 
programs, as well as information on enrolling in the latest research studies. 
 
The morning session begins at 9:30 AM with a welcome by Executive Director, 
Deirdre Phillips. 
 
A plenary session on New Visions for Autism Treatment will feature Christopher 
McDougle, MD, Head of the Lurie Family Autism Center at Massachusetts General 
Hospital; Jean Frazier, MD, Chair of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at the 
University of Massachusetts Medical School and UMass Memorial Medical Center; 
and William Barbaresi, MD, Associate Chief of the Division of Developmental 
Medicine at Children's Hospital Boston. 
 
A talk on Bridging Clinical Care and Clinical Research by Roula Choueiri, MD, a 
Neurodevelopmental Pediatrician at the Floating Hospital for Children at Tufts 
Medical Center will follow. 
 
Next, Dennis Wall, PhD, Assistant Professor of Pathology and Director of the 
Computational Biology Initiative at Harvard Medical School will present on his 
work on Shortening the Behavioral Diagnosis of Autism Through Artificial 
Intelligence and Mobile Health Technologies. 
 
Lunch will offer a poster session highlighting research in progress. 
 
The afternoon will begin with an important and timely session on Relaying 
Research Findings to Families: Ethical and Legal Considerations by Pearl 
O'Rourke, MD, Director, Human Research Affairs at Partners Health Care System. 
 
Following this, Mark Daly, PhD, Associate Professor at the Massachusetts General 
Hospital and Harvard Medical School, and an Associate Member of the Broad 
Institute will provide an update on Autism Genetics: New Advances and Future 
Considerations. 
 
Next Vijaya Ramesh, PhD, Associate Professor of Neurology (Genetics) at Harvard 
Medical School and an Associate Neurologist at MGH will discuss her work on 
Neuronal E3 Ubiquitin Ligase Pam in TSC/mTORC1 Signaling and Synapse 
Development. 
 
Several other talks are being planned and a reception for all will conclude the 
day. 
 
Register here: https://autismconsortium.eventbrite.com/ 
 
Check the website often for updates and the complete agenda at 
www.autismconsortium.org and please share this invitation! 
 
The Symposium will be held at The Joseph B. Martin Conference Center at Harvard 
Medical School, 77 Avenue Louis Pasteur, Boston, MA 02115 
 
For more information 
email: autismconsortium@hms.harvard.edu 
call: 617-432-6961 
________________________________________________________________________________ 
The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT 
 
"Genome-scale analyses of allele-specific expression and DNA methylation" 
 
Andrew Chess, MD 
Professor of Neuroscience 
Professor of Developmental and Regenerative Biology 
Professor of Genetics and Genomic Sciences 
Mount Sinai School of Medicine 
 
6:00 p.m., Wednesday, November 9, 2011 
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception 
Building Address: 43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA 02139 
 
Hosted by Li-Huei Tsai, Ph.D., Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, 
Massachusetts Institute of Technology 
 
Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu 
 
Common diseases clearly have a heritable component. The extent to which 
epigenetic inheritance contributes to heritability, alongside of genetic 
inheritance, remains to be determined. I will discuss our genome-scale 
approaches exploring DNA methylation polymorphism alongside of genetic 
polymorphism. Additionally, I will present our work on random monoallelic 
expression of autosomal genes. Studying the human genome, and more recently the 
mouse genome, we have discovered that random monoallelic expression, similar to 
that observed in X-inactivation, is surprisingly common impacting around 10% of 
autosomal genes. We are currently exploring how this might impact 
genotype-phenotype correlation by studying individual neurons in the brain. 
 
Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT 
(web.mit.edu/autism)

> 
Subject: PLEASE POST: Alexander Gramfort: Brain and Vision Resaerch Lab seminar-October 18th 12pm, ERB705 
 
Formal announcement will follow 
 
Brain and Vision Research Seminar 
 
Ill-posed problems in brain imaging: from MEG source estimation 
to resting state networks and decoding with fMRI. 
 
October 17, 12pm 
Boston University, 44 Cummington str, ERB-705 
 
Host: Lucia M. Vaina 
 
If the number of parameters to estimate exceeds the number 
of measurements, an estimation problem is said to be ill-posed. 
Due to limited acquisition times, physics of the problems 
and complexity of the brain, the field of brain imaging 
needs to address many ill-posed problems. Among such problems 
are: the localization in space and time of active brain regions 
with MEG and EEG, the estimation of functional networks from fMRI 
resting state data and what was is commonly called "decoding". 
Decoding consists in predicting from fMRI data a behavorial 
variable or classifying brain states using supervised learning 
methods like SVM. In this talk I will describe some recent 
contributions to all three problems. The concepts shared 
by the different methods presented are: 
estimation and statistical learning in high dimension, 
convex optimization, sparse and structured priors. 
 
 
Short bio 
--------- 
 
Alexandre Gramfort is currently a research fellow at the Martinos Center for 
Biomedical Imaging in Boston working with Matti Hamalainen. He was previously 
postdoctoral fellow in the INRIA Parietal Project Team in Paris, France. He 
obtained his PhD in 2009 from Telecom ParisTech under the supervision of 
Maureen Clerc and Olivier Faugeras. He did his PhD jointly at INRIA in Sophia 
Antipolis and the Computer Science Department at the Ecole normale supérieure 
in Paris. He graduated from the Ecole Polytechnique in 2006 after a double 
masters degree at Telecom ParisTech and the Ecole normale supérieure in Cachan 
(DEA MVA). His research interests are on brain functional imaging (MEG, EEG, 
fMRI) and in particular on problems involving signal and image processing, 
scientific computing, numerical methods, data mining and machine learning. 
Alexandre Gramfort received an award for his PhD work from the EADS foundation, 
and awards at the Biomag conference in 2010 and HBM conference in 2011 for his 
work on the MEG inverse problem. 
 
Some references 
--------------- 
 
Functional Brain Imaging with M/EEG Using Structured Sparsity in Time-Frequency Dictionaries 
http://www.springerlink.com/content/mp7701m142193w83/ 
 
Brain covariance selection: better individual functional connectivity models using population prior 
http://books.nips.cc/papers/files/nips23/NIPS2010_1054.pdf 
 
Multi-subject Dictionary Learning to Segment an Atlas of Brain Spontaneous Activity 
http://www.springerlink.com/content/c60kgvj402738763/ 
 
Total variation regularization for fMRI-based prediction of behavior. 
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21317080?dopt=Abstract 
 
Multi-scale Mining of fMRI data with Hierarchical Structured Sparsity 
http://fr.arxiv.org/abs/1105.0363

bodyText:
MIT COLLOQUIUM ON BRAIN AND COGNITION  
  Thursday, October 13, 2011, at 4:00 pm, MIT Building 46, Room 3002 
   Speaker :   Dr. Rita Balice-Gordon of University of Pennsylvania 



 Title :  Mechanisms of Autoimmune Synaptopathies 



 Abstract :   Dr. Balice-Gordon's talk will focus on a cohort of recently discovered human autoimmune disorders of memory, learning, cognition, and psychosis in which the function of NMDARs, AMPARs and other synaptic and cell surface proteins is directly affected by patient?s antibodies. These disorders are naturally occurring models of human neuropsychiatric dysfunction that are unique: they are relatively frequent; cause severe memory loss; can be lethal but are potentially treatable; often affect children; and frequently result in the transient misdiagnosis of children and adults on the autism-schizophrenia spectrum. She will discuss recent published work and unpublished results that establish the cellular and synaptic mechanisms underlying these novel autoimmune synaptopathies and mechanisms of recovery, provide insights into cellular and circuit dysfunction caused by patients? antibodies, and begin to connect synaptic and circuit dysfunction with the behavioral abnormalities that are hallmarks of these disorders.

B02. The seminar will begin at the regularly scheduled time, 10:30 AM ~~~ 
 
Friday - October 7 
 
Speaker: Dr. Cara Stepp, Boston University 
 
Title: Relative Fundamental Frequency as an Acoustic Correlate of Laryngeal 
Tension 
 
Abstract: The human voice is vital to communication, and allows us to 
interact with others to express our thoughts, desires, and emotions. 
However, for the 3 - 9% of the U.S. population with a voice disorder, 
communication is impaired, causing them to suffer both economically and 
socially. Vocal hyperfunction is a common cause of and accompaniment to 
voice disorders characterized by excessive laryngeal and paralaryngeal 
tension. Vocal hyperfunction can respond to behavioral intervention, but 
successful treatment is dependent upon proper assessment. Although vocal 
hyperfunction accounts for 10 - 40 % of cases referred to multidisciplinary 
voice clinics, current assessment is hampered by the lack of objective 
measures for detecting its presence or severity.  Our recent findings 
indicate promise for the use of the non-invasive acoustic measure of 
relative fundamental frequency (RFF) as such a measure. RFF is the 
normalized fundamental frequency of vocal cycles immediately before and 
after voiceless consonant production. We have shown RFF to (i) discriminate 
between individuals with and without voice disorders associated with vocal 
hyperfunction, (ii) normalize after successful voice therapy toward values 
seen in unimpaired speakers, and (iii) correlate with listener 
auditory-perception of vocal effort. Our findings support future large-scale 
clinical studies of this measure. 
 
 
***Seminars start at 10:30AM in Room 203 at 44 Cummington St. and end by 
noon.  The event calendar of the HRC talks could be found at 
http://www.bu.edu/dbin/hrc/calendar/. 
 
Come early for coffee and donuts and stay for lunch**

bodyText: Please join us at this talk in the Computation Group Lecture Series, Department of Architecture, MIT:     “It's Not What You Think: An Evolutionary Theory of Spiritual Enlightenment”    October 7, 2011 12:30 - 2:00pm Room 7-431(Long Lounge)      Jeff Lieberman Artist and Scientist, Founder, Plebian Design  Abstract: Take a broad perspective: Evolutionary theory provides us with an unpredictably deep connection with the cosmos — a 13 billion year-old family tree. Your grandfather 300 million years ago was a lizard. How did it experience life? Imagine the conscious experience of a reptile. Elements like vision are similar, but higher functions are absent. Reptile consciousness is, in some way, a definitively 'smaller' version of consciousness than what we have today. As evolution has changed the structure of organisms, so has it changed the subjective experience. Don't forget, before any life existed, you were once rocks, air, and water, with a dash of lightning. This particular pattern of molecules known as a 'human being' has evolved an amazing depth of consciousness: an ability to internally model the reality beyond the senses, to imagine futures that have never happened, to use language, to use rationality to build and test theories about our universe, to become self-aware. We often assume, due to these extreme capabilities, that the average adult consciousness in 2011 is the apex of the evolution of consciousness, and that it is now up to technology to propel us forward. So we work on changing the outside world to suit our needs, instead of changing ourselves and the way our minds function. As consciousness evolves, we gain wider and deeper understandings of the universe and of ourselves. Where might it be headed next and what insights might we find? I believe that we have specific pointers in front of us about the next qualitative stages in our evolution, and where this has led has been surprising. As our evolutionary shifts in consciousness define how we see the world in which we live, there may be nothing more important. Bio: Jeff Lieberman explores the connections between the arts, sciences, education, passion, creativity, and the potential future of human consciousness. He hosts ‘Time Warp’ on the Discovery Channel, composes music in the duo gloobic, and shows technological sculptures around the world. Lieberman finished four degrees at MIT (BS: Physics, Math, MS: Mech. Engineering, Media Arts and Sciences)  We hope to see you all there - please arrive to the lecture on time. For more information please contact:   danielas@mit.edu   and/ or  d_rosen@mit.edu

bodyText: MIT COLLOQUIUM ON   THE BRAIN AND COGNITION   Thursday  , October 06, 2011 | 4:00 pm   MIT Building 46, Room 3002 (Singleton Auditorium)             ABSTRACT:   How does a 0.1-mg brain housed in a 10-mg insect solve complex navigational tasks, which we humans would be able to accomplish only by employing topographic maps, Inertial Navigation or GPS devices?  In trying to answer this question the talk will focus on the extraordinary navigational skills of Cataglyphis , a visually guided desert ant, which has become a model organism for the study of animal navigation.  In the Sahara desert these ants forage individually over distances of several ten thousand times their body lengths and safely return to their starting point.  What do the compass and the odometer look like that the ants use in integrating their paths?  Is the spatial information provided by path integration and, in addition, by special landmark-guidance routines finally integrated into a “cognitive map” of the animal’s foraging terrain?  A multidisciplinary approach combining behavioral and neurophysiological studies with computer simulations and robotics implementations is used to tackle such questions.  The talk deals with the particular navigational routines employed by the insect navigator, and finally concludes that these domain-specific routines interact flexibly within a distributed system rather than feed their information into a coherent global representation of space. What then do we mean when we feel inclined to credit the lowly ant with cognitive capacities?
subject: TODAY BCS COLLOQUIUM SERIES: RUDIGER WEHNER 10/6 @ 4PM

bodyText:
The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT 
 
"Common SNPs, rare CNVs, and the expression network between?" 
 
Lauren A. Weiss, Ph.D. 
Staglin Family/IMHRO Assistant Professor, University of California, San 
Francisco 
 
6:00 p.m., Wednesday, October 5, 2011 
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception 
Building Address: 43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA 02139 
 
Hosted by Mark Daly, Ph.D., Associate Professor of Medicine, Harvard Medical 
School 
 
Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu 
 
Recent genetic studies in common, complex heritable disease like autism spectrum 
disorders have met success in two arenas: geneticists like to divide differences 
among individuals into 'common polymorphisms' and 'rare variants', and often 
argue about which kind of variation will be more important in disease risk. 
Both kinds of results provide challenges to direct translation into 
neurobiological understanding of autism, as they rarely reveal easily 
interpretable protein-coding mutations. Common polymorphism association 
signals often fall in noncoding sequences or between genes, and rare variants 
in autism have primarily been large deletions and duplications including many 
brain-expressed genes. I will describe an approach to 'pathway' definition 
using gene expression data that can unite a number of autism-implicated common 
polymorphisms and rare variants into a network with functional implications. 
 
Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT 
(web.mit.edu/autism)

subject: TONIGHT -- "Common SNPs, rare CNVs, and the expression network between?"

bodyText:
Recursive Deep Learning in Natural Language Processing and Computer Vision 
Speaker: Richard Socher 
Speaker Affiliation: Stanford University 
 
Date: 10-5-2011 
Time: 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM 
Location: G449 (Kiva) 
 
Hierarchical and recursive structure is commonly found in 
different modalities, including natural language sentences and 
scene images. I will present some of our recent work on three 
recursive neural network architectures that learn meaning 
representations for such hierarchical structure. These models 
obtain state-of-the-art performance on several language and 
vision tasks. 
 
The meaning of phrases and sentences is determined by the 
meanings of its words and the rules of compositionality. We 
introduce a recursive neural network (RNN) for syntactic parsing 
which can learn vector representations that capture both 
syntactic and semantic information of phrases and sentences. For 
instance, the phrases "declined to comment" and "would not 
disclose" have similar representations. Since our RNN does not 
depend on specific assumptions for language, it can also be used 
to find hierarchical structure in complex scene images. This 
algorithm obtains state-of-the-art performance for semantic scene 
segmentation on the Stanford Background and the MSRC datasets and 
outperforms Gist descriptors for scene classification by 4%. 
 
The ability to identify sentiments about personal experiences, 
products, movies etc. is crucial to understand user generated 
content in social networks, blogs or product reviews. The second 
architecture I will talk about is based on semi-supervised 
recursive autoencoders (RAE). RAEs learn vector representations 
for phrases sufficiently well as to outperform other traditional 
supervised sentiment classification methods on several standard 
datasets. Lastly, I describe an alternative unsupervised RAE 
model that can learn features which outperform previous 
approaches for paraphrase detection on the Microsoft Research 
Paraphrase corpus. 
 
This talk presents joint work with Andrew Ng and Chris Manning. 
 
 
Bio: 
 
Richard Socher is a Computer Science PhD student at Stanford, 
co-advised by Chris Manning and Andrew Ng. Most recently, he won 
the Yahoo! Key Scientific Challenges Program Award and the 
Distinguished Application Paper Award at ICML, 2011 for his work 
on recursive deep learning. 
 
Relevant URL(S): http://www.socher.org/ 
For more information please contact: David Wingate, 617 324 2894, wingated@mit.edu 
_______________________________________________ 
Bcs-talks mailing list 
Bcs-talks@mit.edu 
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-talks

bodyText:
Folks, It is my pleasure to announce the continuation of student seminar series, featuring Rob Law this Thursday from 4-5pm, in CNS basement.  Refreshments will be served.   Please feel free to pass it along to interested groups.  :) 

 ~NaN  Below is Rob's abstract:  

 Symmetry has played a surprisingly minor role in brain theory despite being vital to most other modern sciences. This is in part because the symmetries of the nervous system are somewhat subtle, with classical group structures appearing less prevalently than a collection of local, groupoid symmetries. The recent dynamical systems literature has offered a compelling and intuitive case relating such structural symmetries to synchrony and phase-locking in networks of coupled dynamical systems. Such an approach is immediately relevant to network modelers who take a deterministic perspective, but related methods have been applied to stochastic systems as well.  

    The detection of symmetries and inference of their dynamical consequences establishes a rough outline of the relationship between a structure and its function. This is a major goal in the biological sciences in general, and to this end, I will present a "physicist's proof" of a theorem relating the left eigenvectors of a network's adjacency matrix to allowed synchronies and phase relationships.  As a corollary, we will find that the Perron-Frobenius eigenvector of this matrix directly indicates a network's "most synchronous" possible state.  We apply this method to reproduce a number of previous computational results and to discover unknown symmetries in some arbitrary networks. Regarding the proof as informal, though, properly formalizing the statement remains a priority. The remainder of the talk will focus on some approaches taken toward this goal, extensions to the method, and speculation on the roles of synchrony and phase in the nervous system.
subject: [CNSO] Student Seminar: Rob Law, Thursday 4-5 pm + Refreshments

bodyText:
Brains and Machines Seminar Series 2011/2012 
Geometry/topology and statistical inference 
Speaker: Sayan Mukherjee 
Speaker Affiliation: Duke University 
Host: Lorenzo Rosasco 
Host Affiliation: Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT); CBCL, MIT 
 
Date: 10-4-2011 
Time: 2:30 PM - 3:30 PM 
Location: Sem Rm G449 (Patil/ Kiva) 
 
In this talk I will illustrate two examples where geometric/topological ideas 
and statistical inference complement each other. In the first example, 
computational geometry is a central tool used to address a classic problem in 
statistics, inference of conditional dependence. In the second example, a 
classic object in topology and geometry, a Whitney stratified space, is stated 
as a mixture model and an algorithm for inference of mixture elements is 
provided as well as finite sample bounds for the algorithm. 
 
The first part of the talk develops a parameterization of hyper-graphs based 
on the geometry of points in d-dimensions, the geometric tool here is the 
abstract simplicial complex. Informative prior distributions on hyper-graphs 
are induced through this parameterization by priors on point configurations 
via spatial processes. The approach combines tools from computational geometry 
and topology with spatial processes and offers greater control on the 
distribution of graph features than Erdos-Renyi random graphs. 
 
In the second part of the talk, I describe the problem of stratification 
learning. Strata correspond to unions and intersections of arbitrary manifolds 
of possibly different dimension. We consider a mixture distribution on the 
strata and formulate the following learning problem: given n points sampled 
iid from the mixture model which points belong to the same strata. I will 
state a bound on the minimum number of sample points required to infer with 
high probability which points belong to the same strata. I will show results 
of this clustering procedure on real data. The clustering procedure uses tools 
from computational topology, specifically persistence homology. 
 
No knowledge of geometry and topology is assumed in the talk. 
 
 
The Brains& Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 is being organized by the 
IIT@MIT lab (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology.) 
 
Relevant URL(S): http://cbcl.mit.edu/

bodyText:
Brains and Machines Seminar Series 2011/2012

Perception, Action and the Information Knot that Ties Them
Speaker: Stefano Soatto
Speaker Affiliation: UCLA
Host: Lorenzo Rosasco
Host Affiliation: Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT); CBCL, MIT

Date: 9-30-2011
Time: 3:00 PM - 4:00 PM
Location: McGovern Seminar Room, MIT 46-3189

Abstract: I will describe a notion of Information for the purpose of decision
and control tasks, rooted in ideas of J. J. Gibson, and is specific to classes
of tasks and nuisance factors affecting the data formation process. When such
nuisances involve scaling and occlusion phenomena, as in most imaging
modalities, the "Information Gap" between the maximal invariants and the
minimal sufficient statistics can only be closed by exercising control on the
sensing process. Thus, sensing, control and information are inextricably tied.
This has consequences in understanding the so-called "signal-to-symbol
barrier" problem, as well as in the analysis and design of active sensing
systems. I will show applications in vision-based control, navigation, 3-D
reconstruction and rendering, as well as detection, localization, recognition
and categorization of objects and scenes in live video.

Speaker: Stefano Soatto is the founder and director of the UCLA Vision 
Lab ( vision.ucla.edu ). He received his Ph.D. in Control and Dynamical 
Systems from the California Institute of Technology in 1996; he joined 
UCLA in 2000 after being Assistant and then Associate Professor of 
Electrical and Biomedical Engineering at Washington University, Research
 Associate in Applied Sciences at Harvard University, and Assistant 
Professor in Mathematics and Computer Science at the University of 
Udine, Italy. He received his D.Ing. degree (highest honors) from the 
University of Padova- Italy in 1992. Dr. Soatto is the recipient of the 
David Marr Prize (with Y. Ma, J. Kosecka and S. Sastry) for work on 
Euclidean reconstruction and reprojection up to subgroups. He also 
received the Siemens Prize with the Outstanding Paper Award from the 
IEEE Computer Society for his work on optimal structure from motion 
(with R. Brockett). He received the National Science Foundation Career 
Award and the Okawa Foundation Grant. He is a Member of the Editorial 
Board of the International Journal of Computer Vision (IJCV), the 
International Journal of Mathematical Imaging and Vision (JMIV) and 
Foundations and Trends in Computer Graphics and Vision. 

The Brains & Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 is being organized by the
IIT@MIT lab (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology.)

Relevant URL(S): http://cbcl.mit.edu/
subject: TALK:Friday 9-30-11 Perception, Action and the Information Knot that Ties Them

bodyText: McGovern Institute Special Seminar   TITLE:  Automated whole-cell patch clamp electrophysiology of   neurons in vivo   SPEAKER:  Suhasa Kodandaramaiah PhD student, Georgia Tech, and visiting PhD student, MIT Laboratories of Craig Forest, Georgia Tech, and Ed Boyden, MIT   PLACE:  Room 46-3189   TIME:  Friday September 30, 2011, 1:30 PM   ABSTRACT:  Whole-cell patch clamp electrophysiology of neurons in vivo enables the recording of electrical events in cells with great precision, and supports a wide diversity of cellular morphological and molecular analysis experiments.  However, high levels of skill are required in order to perform in vivo patching, and the process is time-consuming and painstaking.  An automated in vivo patching robot would not only empower a great number of neuroscientists to perform such experiments, but would also open up fundamentally new kinds of experiment enabled by the resultant high throughput.  We discovered that in vivo blind whole cell patch clamp electrophysiology could be implemented as a straightforward algorithm, and developed an automated robotic system capable of performing this algorithm.  We validated the performance of our robot in both the cortex and hippocampus of anesthetized mice.  Our robot achieves yields, cell recording qualities, and operational speeds that are comparable to, or exceed, those of experienced human investigators, and is simple and inexpensive to implement.
subject: Special Seminar Today at 1:30 PM in 46-3189

The talks will start at 10:30AM in room 203 at 44 Cummington St. 
and go on to noon. The event calendar of the HRC talks could be found at http://www.bu.edu/dbin/hrc/calendar/. 
 
Come early for the coffee and donuts! 
 
================================================= 
 
Friday, April 29, 2011 
10:30AM-noon 
Rm 203, 44 Cummington St. 
 
Professor Frank Guenther 
Department of Speech, Language and Hearing Sciences, Sargent College, Boston University 
 
Title: The neural mechanisms of speech: From computational modeling to neural prosthesis 
 
Abstract: Speech production is a highly complex sensorimotor task involving tightly coordinated processing in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes of the cerebral cortex. To better understand these processes, our laboratory has designed, experimentally tested, and iteratively refined a neural network model whose components correspond to the brain regions involved in speech. Babbling and imitation phases are used to train neural mappings between phonological, articulatory, auditory, and somatosensory representations. After learning, the model can produce syllables and words it has learned by generating movements of an articulatory synthesizer. Because the model's components correspond to neural populations and are given precise anatomical locations, activity in the model's cells can be compared directly to neuroimaging data. Computer simulations of the model account for a wide range of experimental findings, including data on acquisition of speaking skills, articulatory ! 
 kinematics, and brain activity during speech. Furthermore, "damaged" versions of the model are being used to investigate several communication disorders, including stuttering, apraxia of speech, and spasmodic dysphonia. Finally, the model was used to guide development of a neural prosthesis aimed at restoring speech output to a profoundly paralyzed individual with an electrode permanently implanted in his speech motor cortex. The volunteer maintained a 70% hit rate after 5-10 practice attempts of each vowel in a vowel production task, supporting the feasibility of brain-machine interfaces with the potential to restore conversational speech abilities to the profoundly paralyzed.

bodyText: From: Ada Kwok [mailto: akwok@bu.edu ] To: SAR faculty & staff Subject: Research Seminar - Tuesday, May 3, 2011   ****************************** ****************************** ****************************** ********************* Hi everyone, You are invited to attend the following research seminar: Boston University Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences Research Colloquium Series Jenny Thomson, Ph.D., CCC-SLP Assistant Professor Harvard Graduate School of Education PRESENTS:  Is assistive technology really assistive? "Written communication is evolving from a pen and paper activity to one frequently carried out using a computer, with the pace of change outstripping our ability to understand the effects upon individuals’ ability to demonstrate knowledge. While there is evidence that the use of technology may help with lower level writing processes such as proofreading, grammar and spelling, early reports of the effects on higher level writing processes, required for success in higher education and the workplace, are mixed. This talk reports a study evaluating the impact of mode (pen versus keyboard) upon higher level writing performance for students with and without learning disabilities. The results provide insights into the strengths and limitations of current technologies in facilitating acquisition and demonstration of knowledge, as well as how this may vary among different populations of learners. " DATE:  Tuesday, May 3, 2011 TIME:  12:00-1:00 pm LOCATION:  SARGENT Rm. 220 Refreshments will be served. Best wishes, Ada   Ada Kwok Assistant to the Chairman Department of Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences Boston University Sargent College 635 Commonwealth Ave. Boston, MA  02215 Phone:  617/353-3252 Fax:  617/353-5074

bodyText:
Hi all, 
 
More information about Riitta Hari's talk is included below. 
 
- Matti 
 
--------------- 
 
MGH / Martinos Center (Charlestown Navy Yard, building 149, room 2204 
May 4 at noon 
 
Time scales of human brain function: Insights from behavioral measures and neuromagnetic recordings 
 
Riitta Hari 
Brain Research Unit 
Aalto University School of Science 
Finland 
hari@neuro.hut.fi 
 
Human percepts, cognition, and actions are coordinated in a temporally accurate manner, with the relevant timescales ranging from milliseconds to several seconds. Multiple time scales typically govern the same behavior. During social interaction, such as free conversation, the speaker's articulation movements and other expressions change at time scales from tens to hundreds of milliseconds, and the prediction of and the reaction to the other speaker's talking can vary rapidly. — I will discuss the role of magnetoencephalography (MEG), both evoked responses and the reactivity of brain rhythms, in assessing the dynamics of the rapidly changing human percepts and actions. My dream would be to move towards “2-person neuroscience”, to study—in not too distant future—the brain basis of social interaction in real time. 
 
References: 
Hari R and Kujala MV: Brain basis of human social interaction. From concepts to brain imaging. Physiol Reviews 2009, 89: 453–479. 
Hari R, Parkkonen L and Nangini C: The brain in time: Insights from neuromagnetic recordings. The Year in Cognitive Neuroscience 2010, Ann NY Acad Sci 2010, 1191: 89–109. 
 
 
 
 
 
--------- 
 
Matti Hamalainen, Ph.D. 
Athinoula A. Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging 
Massachusetts General Hospital 
 
msh@nmr.mgh.harvard.edu
